review.title: Sparsity-based Correction of Exponential Artifacts
review.abstract: This paper describes an exponential transient excision algorithm (ETEA). In biomedical time series analysis, e.g., in vivo neural recording and electrocorticography (ECoG), some measurement artifacts take the form of piecewise exponential transients. The proposed method is formulated as an unconstrained convex optimization problem, regularized by smoothed l1-norm penalty function, which can be solved by majorization-minimization (MM) method. With a slight modification of the regularizer, ETEA can also suppress more irregular piecewise smooth artifacts, especially, ocular artifacts (OA) in electroencephalog- raphy (EEG) data. Examples of synthetic signal, EEG data, and ECoG data are presented to illustrate the proposed algorithms.

sections.text: ar Xiv: 150 9.07 234v 1 [cs.L G] 24 Sep 20This paper describes an exponential transient excision algorithm (ETEA). In biomedical time series analysis, e.g. in vivo neural recording and electrocorticography (ECoG), some measurement artifacts take the form of piecemeal exponential transients. The proposed method is formulated as an unrestricted convex optimization problem, regulated by a smoothed 1-standard tightening function that can be solved by majorization minimization method (MM). With a slight modification of the regulator, ETEA can also suppress irregular, piecemeal smooth artifacts, especially eye artifacts (OA) in electroencephalography (EEG) data. Examples of synthetic signals, EEEEG and ECoG data are presented to illustrate the proposed algorithms.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This work is motivated by the problem of suppressing different types of artifacts in neural activity records. In a recent study [25], typical artifacts in in vivo neural records are divided into four types (type 0 to 3, see section 2.2 and figure 3 in [25]).This classification includes many artifacts in the scope of human brain activity records, e.g. the type of electroencephalography (EEG) and electrocorticography (ECoG).In this paper, we look at the suppression of type 0 and type 1 artifacts. For the purpose of flexibility and generality, we redefine them in terms of morphological characteristics: • Type 0: a smooth protuberance that can be modelled as x (t) when t > t0 and type 1 artifacts (type 1: an abrupt jump followed by an exponential decay) that follows as x.

sections.heading: 1.1 Related works
sections.text: Some recent work uses transients to recover from different algorithms. In [19], a slowly varying signal is modeled as a local polynomial and an optimization problem with Tikhonov regularization to capture it. In [47], the slowly varying trend is modeled as a sparse derivative (e.g., the third derivative is sparse). Instead of estimating the slowly varying component using regularization, the LPF / TVD method estimates a low-pass component through LTI filtering and a piecewise constant component through optimization. In this case, an optimization problem is formulated to estimate the piecewise constant component through regulation.

sections.heading: 2.3 Majorization-Minimization
sections.text: Majorization Minimization (MM) [15, 35, 57] is a method to replace a difficult optimization problem with a more simple sequence [15, 24, 36, 57]. Suppose a minimization problem has an objective function J: RN → R, then the majorizer G (u, v): RN · RN → R satisfiesG (u, v) = J (u), if u = v, (9a) G (u, v) > J (u), if u 6 = v. (9b), then MM iterative solvesu (k + 1) = argmin u (u, u (k)) (10) to convergence where k is iteration index. Detailed derivation and proof of convergence of MM are given in [35].

sections.heading: 3 Majorization of smoothed penalty function
sections.text: When using sparsely regulated optimizations to restore a signal, the "1 standard" is often used. To further increase the "sparseness," some methods use iterative re-weighting methods [4, 34, 45, 63] or a non-convex pseudo-p standard (0 < p < 1) or a mixed standard in the regulator [5, 68, 66, 58, 33]. Other non-convex tightening functions can also be used. In [46], a logarithm tightening function is discussed ("logarithm function" in Table 1) and in [59] an arctangenic function ("atan" function table Table 1). However, each of these functions is non-differentiable at zero, with "(0 −) 6 =" digit "(0 +)" (0 +) as "digit" (0 +) (0 +) as "digit" (0 +). A method to avoid the discontinuity in derivative.

sections.heading: 4.4 Example: synthetic signal
sections.text: To illustrate ETEA, the algorithm is tested on a simulated signal and compared with other methods. Figure 3 shows the test signal and its components: a low-pass signal f, a transient component x, composed of three exponential decades and white Gaussian noise with σw = 0.20. Noise observation is shown in Figure 3 in gray.Denoising. The result of conventional low-pass filtering is shown in Figure 4a. The result is smooth, but the step margins of each pulse are diminished. If the result is compared with the true low-pass baseline, the result is also distorted. The result of using LPF / TVD [61] is illustrated in Figure 4b. Although the abrupt jumps have been preserved, serious stair effects appear. LPF / TVD uses the derived operator D in regulation.

sections.heading: 4.5 Example: artifact removal of ECoG data
sections.text: Conventional EEG studies and most clinical EEG applications are limited to below 75 Hz [51]. Advanced measurement methods such as ECoG record multi-channel cortical potentials from the microelectrodes within the human skull at a higher sampling rate. In this example, we use a 5-second epoch of the ECoG signal, with a sampling rate of 2713 Hz, recorded by a mesial temporal epilepsy (MTLE) patient. Figure 6a shows the raw data in gray and the corrected data from ETEA in black. There are two Type 1 artefacts identified in this 5-second epoch, one is at about t = 1.20 seconds, and the other at about t = 3.60 seconds. In the signal model (1), the suppression of component x, which represents artifacts, the corrected data (f + w) should preserve the components. We show the corrected data in Figure 6a where the two spikes are correct.

sections.heading: 5 Higher-order ETEA
sections.text: In the previous section, we introduced ETEA based on the signal model (1), which is suitable for type 1 artifacts where component x has discontinuous step exponential transients. Here, we illustrate another version of ETEA based on the signal model (1), in which component x has type 0 artifacts. First, we consider the operator R2: = r2 − 2r 1 r2 − 2r 1...... r2 − 2r 1, (45) in which component x has three non-zero coefficients in each line. As a special case, if r = 1, R2 is the second-order differential operator and the regulator used in [30] for a detection component. If R2 is used as a filter, the transmission function isR2 (z) x x x, (1 − rz − 1) 2, which has a double zero at z =.

sections.heading: 5.2 Example: ocular artifacts suppression

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: The first algorithm, ETEA, assumes that the signal consists of a low-pass signal and an exponential transient (type 1). It is formulated as an optimization problem regulated by a differentiated and smooth tightening function. The second algorithm is an extension of ETEA, using a higher order recursive filter applicable to the correction of continuous protuberance transients (type 0) and irregular artifacts. As applications, we have shown that ETEA with different regulators (R and R2) are suitable for the suppression of type 1 artifacts in ECoG data and ocular artifacts (OA) (as sequential type 0 artifacts) in conventional EEG data. Both methods of the above terms are efficiently compressed, as they are promising in future work.

metadata.abstractText: This paper describes an exponential transient excision algorithm (ETEA). In biomedical time series analysis, e.g., in vivo neural recording and electrocorticography (ECoG), some measurement artifacts take the form of piecewise exponential transients. The proposed method is formulated as an unconstrained convex optimization problem, regularized by smoothed l1-norm penalty function, which can be solved by majorization-minimization (MM) method. With a slight modification of the regularizer, ETEA can also suppress more irregular piecewise smooth artifacts, especially, ocular artifacts (OA) in electroencephalography (EEG) data. Examples of synthetic signal, EEG data, and ECoG data are presented to illustrate the proposed algorithms.
